importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The Ostwall complex was abandoned by the Nazis in 1945, marking the end of its wartime military use and the beginning of its postwar decay.
The London Tunnels are expected to open to the public in 2028, signaling a major new phase in the development of underground tourism in the UK.
A seven-foot 'monster' in West Virginia shut down schools in 1967, a pivotal event that led to public inquiries and ongoing interest in the town’s mysterious history.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The Nazi construction of the Ostwall complex occurred between 1930 and 1945, during which it served as a major fortified military installation for thousands of soldiers.
The London Tunnels have undergone a $149 million transformation since 2020, aiming to open to the public by 2028 as a premier dark tourism destination.

keyTakeAways: The Ostwall, built by the Nazis in Poland, is now a dark tourism site with 19 miles of tunnels open to visitors via the Międzyrzecz Fortified Region Museum.
The Passage of Commodus in Rome, named after Emperor Commodus, is a 2,000-year-old tunnel where he allegedly survived an assassination attempt, now opening to the public.
The London Tunnels, built during WWII to shelter citizens and later used by the Special Operations Executive, are being redeveloped into a $149 million tourist attraction set to open in 2028.
Kayaköy in Turkey, abandoned after the Greco-Turkish War, is now a ghost town, offering eerie, green-covered walking tours to visitors.
Babylon in Iraq, a once-mighty ancient city, remains a site of historical significance despite overgrown ruins and limited facilities.
The Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum in West Virginia, once a place of medical compassion, is now a haunted tourist attraction known for its paranormal elements and complex history.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Ostwall is central to the article as a former military site now repurposed into a dark tourism destination, highlighting the transition from wartime secrecy to public curiosity.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pniewo serves as the geographic setting for the Ostwall complex, grounding the narrative in a real-world location with historical and cultural context.

namedEntities.name: Międzyrzecz Fortified Region Museum

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This museum plays a key role in the article by providing a modern, educational, and tourist-focused interpretation of the Nazi underground complex.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The tunnel is highlighted as a historical site of intrigue and danger, now opening to the public as part of a broader story on underground Roman structures.

namedEntities.name: London Tunnels

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The London Tunnels are a key focus of the article as a Cold War-era secret facility being transformed into a major tourist attraction in 2028.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Babylon is cited as a symbol of ancient civilization under threat, emphasizing the fragility of historical preservation.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The asylum exemplifies how former institutions of suffering can be repurposed into macabre but commercially successful tourist experiences.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article explores various underground and abandoned sites around the world, highlighting their historical significance and transformation into tourist attractions. Central to the narrative is the Nazi-built Ostwall complex in Poland, a 20-mile underground labyrinth abandoned in 1945 and now open to the public as part of the Międzyrzecz Fortified Region Museum. The story also includes the Roman Passage of Commodus, where Emperor Commodus allegedly survived an assassination attempt, now set to open to the public. Additionally, the London Tunnels, once used as a WWII shelter and by the Special Operations Executive, are undergoing a $149 million renovation to become a premier dark tourism destination by 2028. Other sites—such as the abandoned Turkish ghost town Kayaköy and ancient Babylon in Iraq—illustrate how history, conflict, and decay shape the modern visitor experience. The article underscores how these once-secret or forgotten spaces are now being reinterpreted for public interest, blending history, mystery, and tourism.
title: Deep underground, the Nazis built a city for thousands of soldiers. Now it’s a tourist attraction
